awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Regulating homogeneous and heterogeneous mechanisms in six-electron water oxidation
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor John A. Keith of the University of Pittsburgh and Professor Maureen H.  Tang of Drexel University are supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry to conduct a combined experimental/theoretical study to understand the formation of ozone through the electrocatalytic oxidation of water.  The largest use of ozone (O3) is in the preparation of pharmaceuticals, synthetic lubricants, and other commercially-useful organic compounds. Ozone is also used to kill bacteria in municipal drinking water.  Electrochemical ozone production involves heterogeneous (on electrode surfaces) and homogeneous (in solution) chemical steps.  Specifically, the study seeks to understand how and why this process occurs the way it does through the use of computational catalysis modeling in tandem with experimental measurements.  Once the mechanism is established, recently developed computational high-throughput screening methods will be used to theoretically design and experimentally validate catalysts for ozone production.  The project is expected to deliver fundamental knowledge on electrocatalytic reactions.  Success is expected to satisfy the basic societal need for such a commodity.  Students are trained in combined experimental and theoretical chemistry research tools.  Middle schools in urban areas with high populations of underrepresented groups are targeted with outreach plans.  Existing activities that leverage the facilities of the Office of Diversity and Drexel's Lindy Center are continued and expanded.  

The project addresses the production of ozone via electrocatalytic oxidation of water. Specifically, the study seeks to understand how and why electrochemical steps occur in solution phase (homogeneously) and on an electrode surface (heterogeneously).  Computational catalysis modeling while accounting for local solvation environments are combined with experimental ex situ electron paramagnetic resonance studies, differential electrochemical mass spectroscopy, and photocatalysis techniques to develop a complete understanding of the electrochemical ozone production mechanism (EOP).  Three basic scientific questions are addressed: 1) what is the key EOP intermediate that leads to ozone and how is it generated? 2) why do certain catalyst materials and configurations uniquely improve EOP selectivity? and 3) can improved mechanistic understanding lead to novel and improved EOP catalysts? This project is expected to lay important foundational work that is needed to understand fundamental electrocatalysis reaction mechanisms that involve homogeneous and heterogeneous steps.  It is also expected to validate EOP as a means to sustainable production of ozone.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
This project was focused on elucidating atomistic mechanisms for six-electron water oxidations that would electrochemically generate ozone from water.  At the onset of the project, there were open questions about the precise role of Ni dopants in promising antimony and tin-doped tin oxide (NATO) electrodes and to what extent the overall mechanism was dictated by heterogeneous mechanisms (involving surface adsorbed species) and homogeneous mechanisms (involving aqueously solvated species).  We hypothesized that both classes of mechanisms would potentially be in play, and so we collaborated with Prof. Maureen Tang's group at Drexel University to interrogate possible mechanisms to evaluate those that were in best agreement between experimental observations and first principles computational chemistry modeling.

In the early stages of the project, our group was independently focused on developing novel computational methods that would have potential use in high throughput screening of water oxidation catalysts. That resulted in two scientific publications that discussed opportunities and strategies for novel computational modeling approaches in this area. 

https://doi.org/10.1002/aic.17041
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c11345

Our first collaborative publication was entitled "Gd-Ni-Sb-SnO2 electrocatalysts for active and selective ozone production". In this work, Dr. Tang's group provided experimental evidence of Gd dopants having a positive benefit for electrocatalysis, while we provided first principles calculations of strictly homogeneous reaction energies compared to strictly heterogeneous reaction energies and found that neither pathway observed from computational modeling could be correlated with experimental observations. This showed that more work was needed to clarify ozone-producing reaction mechanisms.  

https://doi.org/10.1002/aic.17486

That study indicated to us that the actual mechanism was more complicated than the standard modeling protocol was considering, and so we set to make our models more complex by considering more possibilities of atomic configurations on the surface that would be influenced by environmental factors such as local pH and applied potentials. Our group became invested in computational investigations of heterogeneous reaction mechanisms and received support from Brookhaven National Lab's Center for Functional Nanomaterials in the form of expertise and computational resources needed to carry out greater numbers of more complex atomic scale models. 

This effort helped us identify key reaction energies in the form of redox potentials that correlated with experimental observations from Prof. Tang's group that indicated that the NATO electrodes were potentially decomposing (i.e. corroding) more substantially than had been reported previously in the literature.  Through close collaborations, we could identify elementary oxidation processes that were relatable to the formation of ions and radicals that could be implicated in homogeneous reaction steps.  A key point was that these radicals would only be expected to form in the presence solution phase metal ions such as Nickel(II) that would only appear in solution if the electrode surface were corroding.  These results were published in ACS Catalysis in the final year of the project, and this work generated significant attention from online scientific communication channels, placing it in the top 5% of all research outputs scored by Altmetric.

https://doi.org/10.1021/acscatal.4c01317

This work also helped stimulate hypotheses about doping strategies to improve NATO electrocatalyst performance for water oxidation to generate ozone, and this work has been submitted to a peer-review journal. 

In sum, this project contributed to at least seven peer-reviewed articles, the four listed above, a collaborative perspective that discusses opportunities and challenges in data-centric deep learning strategies for electrocatalysis (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.coche.2022.100824) and two other manuscripts that are submitted and/or under different stages of revision.  The project also resulted in opportunities for students to complete PhD projects and give scientific presentations are conferences to communicate their findings.  

To summarize the intellectual merits, this project made significant contributions to advance the understanding of water oxidation mechanisms on NATO that generate ozone. Specifically, our findings show that simplistic models useful in catalysis are not adequate to describe more complex ozone generating mechanisms, better agreement is found by enumerating hypothetical intermediates that would form under different environmental conditions, and the role of corrosion in producing ozone has likely been underappreciated in the literature.  The project also allowed for fundamental studies to better understand how modern computational chemistry methods can be best leveraged for high throughput screening studies in the future.

To summarize the broader impacts, this project made significant contributions toward understanding why NATO electrodes appear to generate ozone from water, and we are beginning to better appreciated new strategies to dope electrodes to improve electrocatalytic performance.  These findings would potentially be transferrable to other electrocatalytic processes that involve interplays of homogeneous and heterogeneous mechanisms that may also involve corrosion.  

 

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2024
Modified by: John A Keith
